encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be further explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character’s status as majuscule or minuscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

rdg.l: when the best of Kings was imprisoned
by the worst of Rebels at Holmbie

app.rdg: The Complaint of ThamesThe complaint, a common poetic form of the day, is voiced by the river Thames, which flows eastwards from Gloucestershire to London (hence the “western spring” in l. 3). The Thames mourns the imprisonment of King Charles at Holmby, a Northamptonshire estate (also known as Holdenby House) where King Charles was imprisoned after his surrender in the civil war in 1647., 1647, When the Best of Kings was Imprisoned by the Worst of Rebels at Holmby

The Complaint of Thames, 1647, When the Best of Kings Was Imprisoned By the Worst of Rebels at HolmbyAlso known as Holdenby House, Holmby is the estate in Northamptonshire where King Charles I was held prisoner during the latter stages of the First Civil War (February to June 1647). This is one of three poems that Pulter dated 1647. See The Invitation to the Country and Made When I Was Sick, 1647.

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.
I have modernized spelling and punctuation in this poem with the aim of enhancing clarity and readability. The notes gloss unfamiliar words and provide cultural and literary contexts.

In this political-pastoral complaint (in iambic pentameter couplets), the narrator discovers the river Thames mourning the imprisonment of King Charles I in 1647 and the national crisis that has ensued because of the civil war. The use of a frame tale and an embedded narrator was common in Renaissance complaint poems (by William Shakespeare, Samuel Daniel, Thomas Lodge, and others). In this poem, however, Pulter creates a personification of a topographical feature, who testifies to the decline of England and lauds the glory of Charles I and past English rulers (whose erotically-described travel over her waters made her the envy of all the rivers of the world). After inventorying world rivers and mourning the loss of their admiration, the Thames fantasizes that she might stream underground and transport Cromwell and parliamentary authorities to a hellish classical underworld. She then offers to immortalize the king with the only material she can offer: the watery tears of grief.

Framed by a brief first-person introduction and conclusion, “The Complaint of Thames” voices the lament of the Thames river, personified as a female figure, for the betrayal of the rightful monarch, King Charles I, by the people and city of London. Pulter examines the political consequences of the king’s imprisonment in both national and global contexts through the device of a catalog of rivers. Drawing upon extensive geographical and historical lore, Pulter heightens the pathos of the Thames’s complaint by putting it into dialogue with the famous rivers of England and the world. The rivers alternately envy the Thames and grieve with her, joined, finally, by the speaker who puts off sleep to weep with the rivers of the world.

app.rdg: Late in an evening as I walk’d alone,
Late in an evening as I walked alone,
Late in an evening as I walked alone,
I heard the Thames most Sadly make her moane:
I heard the Thames most sadly make her moan.
I heard the Thames most sadly make her moan.
As Shee came weeping from her western Spring,
As she came weeping from her western spring,
As she came weeping from her western springThe Thames flows from west to east across southern England, passing through Oxford and London. Its source is in Gloucestershire.,
Shee thus bewaild the learned Shepherds King.
She thus bewailed the learnéd shepherd’s kingKing Charles, figured as the head of a courtly flock:

She
Pulter personifies the Thames as a feminized figure, thus drawing on the tradition of complaint poetry such as Samuel Daniel’s “The Complaint of Rosamund” and Spenser’s “The Ruines of Time.” In Spenser’s poem, the speaker stands by the river Thames and overhears the complaint of a woman who speaks as the spirit of Verulamium, an ancient Roman city. Some well known poems, such as Michael Drayton’s Poly-Olbion, identified the Thames as masculine. In John Denham’s popular “Cooper’s Hill” (1642), likewise, the Thames is personified as a “son” of the Ocean:
Thames, the most lov’d of all the ocean’s sons,
By his old sire to his embraces runs,
Hasting to pay his tribute to the sea,
Like mortal life to meet eternity. (lines 187-90)
thus bewailed the learned shepherds’ king:
Amintas Sad Amintas Sits forelorne
“Amintascommon male pastoral name for a shepherd; the female equivalent is Chloris, mentioned in the next line., sad Amintas, sits forlorn,
Amintas, sad Amintas, sits forlorn,
And his faire Cloris now’s become the Scorne
And his fair Chloris now’s become the scorn
And his fair Chlorisa pastoral name for Queen Henrietta Maria, paired with Amintas for King Charles. now’s become the scorn
Of Troynovants ingrateblotted letters, possibly “ar,” between “r” and “a” licentious Dames

Of Troynovant’sThe name given by the early chroniclers to London, which was presumed to be built by Brutus, a Trojan refugee; it indicates the city of the Trinovantes or The New Troy. ingrateungrateful licentious dames.

Of TroynovantNew Troy, i.e. London; a name that draws upon the legend that London was founded by the Trojan hero Brutus.’s ingrate, licentious damesIn contrast to the sympathetic Royalism shared by the speaker and the personified Thames, the women of London are represented as immoral and treacherous. During the 1640s some London women did bring petitions before Parliament, political actions that were satirized in sexualized terms in pamphlets such as The Parliament of Women(1646). See Mihoko Suzuki Subordinate Subjects: Gender, the Political Nation, and Literary Form in England, 1588-1688 (Ashgate, 2003), especially chapter 4..
Noe merveile then if poore aflicted Thames
No marvel, then, if poor afflicted Thames
No marvel, then, if poor afflicted Thames
With Salt abortive teares dos wash this Citty
With salt, abortivefruitless tears does wash this city,
With salt abortive tears does wash this city,
As full of Blood and lies as voyd of pittie
As full of blood and lies as void of pity.
As full of blood and lies as void of pity.
Perfidious Town know thou the power of fate
Perfidiousuntrustworthy town, know thou the power of fate:
Perfidiousfaithless or treacherous (OED) town, know thou the power of fate.
Thy long felicitie shall find a date
Thy long felicity shall find a datecome to an end,
Thy long felicity shall find a date,
And I may live to see another turn
And I may live to see another turnof Fortune’s wheel,
And I may live to see another turn
When thy proud fabriackstruck-through “a” crossed out with two forward slashes shall unpittied burn
When thy proud fabricedifice; structure shall unpitied burn.
When thy proud fabric shall unpitied burn.
Then Heaven Just Heaven withhold thy raine
Then Heaven, just Heaven, withhold thy rain,
Then Heaven, just Heaven, withhold thy rain,
And I will leave my channill once againe
And I will leave my channel once again,
And I will leave my channel once again,
As when my holy Albians blood was spilt

As when my holy Albion’scould refer to St. Alban or to Albion. Eardley: St. Alban, killed in the third century AD for harboring a priest; at his urging, God dried up waters so that he could cross a stream to be executed and complete his martyrdom; Albion, another name for Britain, from a giant slain by Hercules, whose spilt blood would reference civil war blood was spilt;

As when my holy AlbianSaint Alban is known as the first British martyr (3rd or 4th century). Alban harbors a priest and refuses to renounce Christianity. When his execution by beheading is ordered, he approaches his death eagerly and when he reaches a quickly flowing river that cannot be crossed, he prays, and the river dries up. In Bede’s Ecclesiastical History of the English People this event is located at the River Ver in the town of Verulamium (now St. Albans), but in another early source (Gildas, De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae) Alban crosses the Thames before his martyrdom, which corresponds to Pulter’s version of the story.’s blood was spilt,
Seeing“e”s are unusual in shape to wash away thy Horrid guilt
Seekingcorrected from “seeing” in the manuscript to wash away thyLondon’s horrid guilt
Seeing to wash away thy horrid guilt
Is more impossible then tis to change
Is more impossible than ’tis to change
Is more impossible than ’tis to change
The Skins“S” written over initial “K”; final “s” written over imperfectly erased “g” of Negros that in Aphrick range

The skins of Negroes that in Afric rangeAfric, or Africa; this line and the one above it allude to the biblical phrase naming impossibility: “Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?” (Jeremiah 13:23), which was proverbial in early modern England.

The skins of Negroes that in Afric’ rangeJeremiah 13:23: “Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots? Then may ye also do good, that are accustomed to do evil” (AV); i.e. the Londoners’ guilt is immutable..
Then when thou fryest in vengfull flames of fire
Then, when thou fryest in vengeful flames of fire,
Then when thou fryest in vengeful flames of fire,
Thy Scorched genious Reddy to expire
Thy scorchéd geniusspirit ready to expire—

Thy scorched geniusi.e. genius loci, “A guardian spirit or god associated with a place” (OED), in this case, the Thames, which withholds its water to punish the “slander” of the Londoners’ tongues. ready to expire,
Thy Tongue and mouth Sable as Salamander
Thy tongue and mouth sableblack as salamanderlizard-like animal, some of which have a black color, supposedly able to endure fire
Thy tongue and mouth sable as salamander
With Speaking gainst thy King and Queene Such Sland’r
With speaking ’gainst thy king and queen such slander—
With speaking ’gainst thy king and queen such slander,
Then not a drop of my coole Cristall Wave
Then not a drop of my cool crystal havemodified from "wave" in the manuscript
Then not a drop of my cool crystal wave
To coole thy Sulpherous Tongue or life to save
To cool thy sulfurousfiery; hellish tongue, or life to save;
To cool thy sulfurous tongue or life to save,
But when I haue of thee Seene all my lust
But when I have of thee seen all my lustpleasure; desire; vigor
But when I have of thee seen all my lust
And all thy pride and Glory Turn’d to dust
And all thy pride and glory turned to dust,
And all thy pride and glory turned to dust,
Then I Triumphant with my watery traine
Then I, triumphant with my watery train,
Then I triumphant with my watery train
Will make this Cittie Quagmires once againe
Will make this city quagmireswet boggy lands that give way under foot; a situation that is unpleasant or hazardous, or from which it is difficult to extricate oneself once again.

Will make this city quagmires“an area of wet, boggy land that gives way under foot; a quaking bog” (OED, “quagmire,” n. 1.); the Thames first threatens to abandon the city of London to drought because of its betrayal of the king. She will return only when she has witnessed (“seen all my lust”) sufficient humbling and punishment (“all thy pride and glory turned to dust”). once again.
But O thy Blood and Pe^rjuries Repent
But O, thyLondon bloodresponsibility for violence or bloodshed and perjuries repent;
But O, thy blood and perjuries repent,
Then Heaven I hope in mercie will Relent
Then Heaven, I hope, in mercy will relent.
Then Heaven I hope in mercy will relent.
Thy King Restore call whome“w” blotted and crossed with forward slashes; “e” crowded into space before next word his Queene againe
Thy king restore, call home his queenHenrietta Maria, King Charles’s wife again,
Thy king restore, call home his queen again,
Or all thy prayer and fasting is in vaine
Or all thy prayer and fasting is in vain.
Or all thy prayer and fasting is in vain.
Hast thou forgot (Aye me) Soe have not I
Hast thou forgot? Ay me—so have not I—
Hast thou forgot (ay me), so have not I,
Those Halcian dayes the Sweete Tranquillity
Those halcyonpeaceful days, the sweet tranquility

Those halcyon daysa period of calm weather that occurs around the winter solstice (OED “halcyon,” adj. 1) and, by extension, the time of peace and prosperity enjoyed by Britain during the rule of Charles I., the sweet tranquility
That wee injoyed Under his happy Reigne
That we enjoyed under his happy reign,
That we enjoyed under his happy reign,
Which Heaven will once Restore to us againe
Which heaven will once restore to us again,
Which Heaven will once restore to us again,
Unles the dismale line of dissolution
Unless the dismal line of dissolution

Unless the dismal line of dissolution“separation into parts or constituent elements; reduction of any body or mass to elements or atoms; destruction of the existing condition; disintegration, decomposition” OED, "dissolution," n.1a.). The Thames worries that a “dismal line of dissolution” will be brought upon the nation, which perhaps anticipates a break in succession or inheritance.
(Which ô forbid) bee drawn upon this Nation.
(Which O, forbid) be drawnforced, traced (figuratively) upon this nation.
(Which oh, forbid) be drawn upon this nation.
Oft have I born upon my Silver Brest
Oft have I born upon my silver breastforefront, face, swelling or supporting surface
Oft have I borne upon my silver breast
His lovely Cloris like Aurora drest
His lovely Chloris, like AuroraRoman goddess of the dawn dressed

His lovely Chloris like Aurora dressedHenrietta Maria costumed as a goddess (Aurora) for a masque, as she was in William Davenant and Inigo Jones’s Luminalia (1638). See note 106 in Alice Eardley, Poems, Emblems, and The Unfortunate Florinda. Pulter addresses and refers to Aurora, the goddess of the dawn, frequently throughout the manuscript, including Aurora [1], To Aurora [1], To Aurora [2], To Aurora [3], and Aurora [2].,
With youth and bevty with her Princely Spouse
With youth and beauty, with her princely spouse.
With youth and beauty, with her princely spouse.
Envied I was by Severn Humber Owes
Envied I was by Severn, Humber, Ousemajor rivers in England;

Envied I was by Severn, Humber, OusePulter here develops an extensive catalog of the world’s rivers. The Thames boasts that the famous rivers of Britain (Severn, Humber, Ouse, and Dee), Europe (Danube, Tagus, Loire, Po, and Tiber), Africa (Nile), Asia (Ganges), and the Middle East (Euphrates) once envied her because she was home to Charles and Henrietta Maria. Pulter draws upon extensive geographical and historical knowledge in her characterization of each river. Each river announces its greatest glory (e.g., the Danube is the longest; Cleopatra traveled on the Nile; the Ganges received sacrifices of its people; the Euphrates bordered Eden), and then admits that it is the Thames that is superior and deserves its “envy.” When the Thames’s fellow rivers learn that the city has betrayed its monarchs, however, they “envy me no more,” and join with the Thames in its mourning (“with their tears my heavy loss deplore”)..
The Sacred Dee said shee noe more would boast
The sacred Deeriver flowing from Wales across the north of England, sacred because linked to a river goddess said she no more would boast
The sacred Dee said she no more would boast
Her Shewing Conquest on the conquering Coast
Her showing conquest on the conquering coastthe River Dee flows across Wales and England to reach the North Sea,
Her showing conquest on the conquering coast,
Though Edgares Glory from her River Springs
Though Edgar’sEdgar, king of England from 959-979; it was reputed that eight other kings signalled submission to Edgar by rowing him down the River Dee. glory from her river springs,
Though Edgar’s glory from her river springs
When hee in Triumph by eight Captive Kings
When he, in triumph, by eight captive kings
When he in triumph by eight captive kings
Was Rowed upon her famous Crist^ iall Streame
Was rowed upon her famous crystal stream;
Was rowed upon her famous crystal stream;
Those former Honours Shewed now like a dreame
Those former honors showed now like a dream.
Those former honors showed now like a dream.
Nay the Danube Said shee would ner’e Rehearse
Nay, the Danubesecond longest European river said she would ne’er rehearse
Nay, the Danube said she would ne’er rehearse
Her being biggest in the Universe
Her being biggest in the universe.
Her being biggest in the universe.
Even Tagus would not brag of Golden Sands
Even Taguslongest river on the Iberian peninsula, famous for gold-bearing sands would not brag of golden sands,
Even Tagus would not brag of golden sands,
But said shee envied more my happy Strands
But said she envied more my happy strandsshores.
But said she envied more my happy strands;
Soe said the Loyer in envie Poe tooke on

So said the LoireThe Loire agreed. The Loire is the longest river in France.. In envy Polongest river in Italy took onproceeded; began [talking]; or possibly in sense 5 of “to take on” (OED, take, v.): spoke or acted madly or excitedly; showed great agitation or distress.;
So said the Loire. In envy Po looked onMS: “tooke” which appears to be an error.
Though shee were Honour’d by a Phaiton

Though she were honored by a Phaetonson of Helios, the sun god; his scorched body fell into the Eridanus River, later known as the River Po of Italy, when he lost control when attempting to drive the sun-chariot.,
Though she were honored by a Phaeton.
And Egipts Glory Nillus Stately Streame
And Egypt’s glory, NilusNile river, longest in the world, stately stream,
And Egypt’s glory, Nilus, stately stream,
Said her felicities were but a dreame
Said her felicities were but a dream,
Said her felicities were but a dream
When on her or’e flowing waves were seene
When on her o’erflowing waves were seen
When on her o’erflowing waves were seen
The Roman Eagles and her black ey’d Queen
The Roman eagles and her black-eyed queenCleopatra, Queen of Egypt (51-30 BCE); with the eagles, emblems of Rome, pointing to Julius Caesar and Marc Antony, each of whom travelled the Nile.
The Roman eagles and her black-eyed queen.
And Silver Gangers Said the Sacrifice
And silver Gangessacred river in India said the sacrifice
And silver Ganges said the sacrifice
The Banians brought with elevated eyes
The BaniansHindu traders brought with elevated eyes—

The Baniansused during the seventeenth century to refer to people from India and/or followers of Hinduism (OED, banian, n.). Pulter refers to the Hindu practice of cremation of the dead on the banks of the Ganges. brought with elevated eyes,
Though all theire CarcasesSecond “c” overwrites an “a”. by fire calcin’d
Though all their carcasses, by fire calcinedpurified by burning,
Though all their carcasses by fire calcined
Were in her Purifieing Waves Refin’d
Were in her purifying waves refined;
Were in her purifying waves refined;
Though all theire wealth and Treasure in they hurl’d
Though all their wealth and treasure in they hurled,
Though all their wealth and treasure in they hurled,
And Shee were Lady of the Eastern World
And she were Lady of the eastern world—
And she were lady of the eastern world;
Yet all that Glory Shee did count a toye
Yet all that glory she did count a toy,
Yet all that glory she did count a toy
Compar’d Shee Said with happy Thames her Joy

Compared, she said, with happy Thames her joythat is, the Thames’s joy. One common early modern way to signal the possessive form grammatically was called the “his genitive,” in which the word “his” or “her” modified the thing possessed (such as Elizabeth her book)..
Compared, she said, with happy Thames her joy.
Tiber Said of Horatias vallure brave

Tiberriver in Italy flowing through Rome said of Horatiusa Roman hero who volunteered to be one of the last defenders of a bridge over the river Tiber against an Etruscan army intent on invading Rome’s valor brave
Tiber said of Horatius’ valor brave
Shee ne’re would Speake but I the praise should have
She ne’er would speak, but I the praise should have.
She ne’er would speak but I the praise should have.
Cristall Euphratus never did envie
Crystal Euphratesriver near Garden of Eden never did envy
Crystal Euphrates never did envy
The Glory of noe other flowd[?]two additional final letters (likely “ed”) corrected or cancelled; “w” could be corrected to or from “o” but I
The glory of no other flood but I;
The glory of no other flood but I,
Though from a Thousand &ff;ounts her Streame doth spring
Though from a thousand founts her stream doth spring,
Though from a thousand founts her stream doth spring;
Yet did shee never beare soe good a King
Yet did she never bear so good a king.
Yet did she never bear so good a king.
Through lofty Babilon her River flowes
Through lofty Babylonfamous city in ancient Mesopotamia her river flows,
Through lofty Babylon her river flows
And Earthly Paradice Shee doth inclose
And earthly paradise she doth encloseEuphrates is associated with the Garden of Eden, Genesis 2:14.,
And earthly paradise she doth enclose;
Though brave Symerrimus enlarge her fame
Though brave Semiramisqueen of Assyria (811-806 BCE) enlarge her fame,
Though brave Semiramis enlarge her fame,
Yet doth shee envie Still the English Thame
Yet doth she envy still the English Thame.
Yet doth she envy still the English Thame.
But now alas they envie me noe more
But now, alas, they envy me no more,
But now, alas, they envy me no more,
But with theire Teares my heavy loss deplore
But with their tears my heavy loss deplorelament.
But with their tears my heavy loss deplore.
Oft haue I born my Sacred Soveraings Barge
Oft have I born my sacred sovereign’s barge,
Oft have I borne my sacred sovereign’s barge,
Being Richly guilt, most proud of such a charge
Being richly gilt, most proud of such a charge.
Being richly gilt, most proud of such a charge.
My waves would Swell to see his Princely face
My waves would swell to see his princely face,
My waves would swell to see his princely face,
Each billow loth to give his fellow placeto right of line, vertical scribble followed by “f”
Each billow loath to give his fellow place.
Each billow loth to give his fellow place.
Sometimes they would rise to kis his Royall hand
Sometimes they would rise to kiss his royal hand,
Sometimes they would rise to kiss his royal hand,
And hardly would give back at my command
And hardly would give back at my command,
And hardly would give back at my command.
Billow with billow strive withcancelled with scribbles and ruffling Rore
Billow with billow strive, and ruffling roar,
Billow with billow strive, and ruffling roar,
Scorning the blow of either hand or Owre
Scorning the blow of either hand or oar;
Scorning the blow of either hand or oar.
But now insulting on my billowes Ride
But now, insulting, on my billows ride
But now insulting on my billows ride
Th[?]three or four letters cancelled with scribbles, last two likely “gh” Kingdooms Schourg’s and this Citties pride
The kingdom’s scourges and this city’s prideCromwell and parliamentarians in London who had opposed King Charles,
The kingdom’s scourges and this city’s pride,
Which make my Trembling Streame lamenting Rore
Which make my trembling stream lamenting roar,
Which make my trembling stream lamenting roar
And her sad loss w:th troubl^ed brest deplore
And her sad loss with troubled breast deplore.
And her sad loss with troubled breast deplore.
Com kind Caribdis Com ô com and help’s

Come, kind CharybdisIn Greek mythology, a whirlpool found on straits, opposite to Scylla, a threatening six-headed monster surrounded by dogs (mentioned in the next line), come, O come and help’shelp us;
Come kind Charybdis, come, oh come, and help’s;
Sweet louely Scilla bring thy barking whelps
Sweet lovely Scylla, bring thy barking whelpsdogs.
Sweet lovely Scylla, bring thy barking whelps.
Then Should they need noe Monument nor Tombe
Then should theythe kingdom’s scourges need no monument nor tomb,
Then should they need no monument nor tomb,
But Ocianis darke and Horrid Womb
But Oceanus’sIn Greek mythology, the son of Uranus (Heaven) and Gaia (Earth), the personification of the great river believed to encircle the whole world. dark and horrid womb
But Oceanus’ dark and horrid womb
Should them involve but wishes are invaine
Should them involveenvelop. But wishes are in vain:

Should them involveThe Thames invokes famous water monsters (Scylla and Charybdis) to aid her in ridding London of the king’s enemies, who will be washed away to unmarked graves in the ocean (“Oceanus’ dark and horrid womb”).. But wishes are in vain;
I will Rore out my griefe unto the Maine
I will roar out my grief unto the mainthe open sea.
I will roar out my grief unto the main.
Now all the bewty that my Waves adorne
Now all the beauty that my waves adorn
Now all the beauty that my waves adorn
Are Snowey Swans that Sadly Swim forelorne
Are snowy swans that sadly swim, forlorn;
Are snowy swans that sadly swim forlorn;
Nor doe they in they Sun theire &ff;eathers Prune
Nor do they in the sun their feathers prune,
Nor do they in the sun their feathers prune,
As they were wont, nor yet theire Voices Tune
As they were wontaccustomed to do, nor yet their voices tune.
As they were wont, nor yet their voices tune,
Butin left margin, ink mark in shape of a check mark in dispaires hanging theire head and wing
But in despairs, hanging their head and wing,
But in despairs, hanging their head and wing,
This Kingdoms Derges they expireing Sing
This kingdom’s dirgessongs of mourning they, expiring, singswans traditionally were understood to sing when dying.

This kingdom’s dirges they expiring sing
Following the invocations of the mythical Scylla and Charybdis, the Thames turns to a more naturalistic description of swans swimming on the river; however, they sing their own deaths and the death of the kingdom. With this image, Pulter refers to the belief that swans are silent until just before their deaths, when they sing a final song. Thomas Browne examines the origin of and evidence for this belief in Book 3, Chapter 27 of Pseudodoxia Epidemica (Sir Thomas Browne, Selected Writings. Ed. Geoffrey Keynes (University of Chicago Press, 1968), pp. 289-90). Compare Shakespeare’s Othello, where Emilia’s final speech begins:
What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan
And die in music. (5.2.240-42)
Greenblatt, et. al. The Norton Shakespeare, 3rd ed., 2016.
.
O That \itt \ in different hand from main scribe in my Power were to Refuse
O, that it in my power were to refuse
Oh that it in my power were to refuse
To see this Towne like Cristall Arethuse
To see this town like crystal ArethuseArethusa, in classical mythology, the nymph with whom Alpheus fell in love, and who flowed underground to escape him, before being turned into a fountain,

To see this town, like crystal ArethuseArethusa is a nymph transformed into an underground fountain so that she may escape the river god Alpheus. See Ovid, Metamorphoses 5.572-641. While much of the poem describes the envy of the world’s rivers for the Thames, here the Thames expresses envy for Arethuse who is able to escape underground. The Thames wishes to “refuse / To see this town.”.
Below this curssed Earth Iwould hide my head
Below this curséd earth I would hide my head,
Below this cursed Earth I would hide my head,
And run amongst the [?]deleted word, six or seven letters long, starts with “C” and ends with “s” ^Caverns of the Dead
And run amongst the caverns of the dead,
And run amongst the caverns of the dead,
Wherelast “e” crowded into space before next word; “r” appears written over “n” my pure Wave with Acharon should mix
Where my pure wave with Acheronriver of Hades should mix
Where my pure wave with Acheron should mix,
With Leathe, Phlegethon, Cocîtus, Stix;
With Lethe, Phlegethon, Cocytus, Styxrivers of Hades.
With Lethe, Phlegethon, Cocytus, Styx;
Then would I wafte them to the Stigian Shade
Then would Iwaftconvey by water themthe anti-royalists mentioned as the kingdom’s scourges, above, and three lines below (“they”) to the Stygianhellish, gloomy, associated with the River Styx shade,

rdg.seg: Then would I waft them to the stygian shadeThe Thames asks to enter the underworld (“caverns of the dead”) where she can mix her “pure wave” with the five rivers of Hades: Acheron (sorrow or woe), Lethe (forgetfulness), Phlegethon (fire), Cocytus (lamentation), and Styx (hate) and punish the king’s enemies (“rebels”) by ushering them to Hell (“waft them to the stygian shade”).

app.rdg: Examples Unto Reybels to be made
Examples unto rebels to be made.
Examples unto rebels to be made.
Ô my Sad heart these are but foolish dreames
O my sad heart, these are but foolish dreams,
Oh my sad heart, these are but foolish dreams,
&ff;or they Triumph Upon my Conquer’d Streames
For they triumph upon my conquered streams.
For they triumph upon my conquered streams.
Yet this I’le doe while Sighs breaths up my Spring
Yet this I’ll do while sighs breathes upevaporates; exhales; taints my spring:
Yet this I’ll do while sighs breathes up my spring;
I’le trickle teares for my aflicted King
I’ll trickle tears for my afflicted king,
I’ll trickle tears for my afflicted king,
And looke how fare one drop of Cristall Thames
And look how far one drop of crystal Thames
And look how far one drop of crystal Thames
Dothtwo “f”s in left marginrun, so fare I’le Memorise their &ff;ames:
Doth run; so far I’ll memorize their fames,
Doth run, so far I’ll memorize their fames;
Soe shall my griefe imortalise them Names.
So shall my grief immortalize theircorrected from “them” names.”
So shall my grief immortalize them names.
I hearing these complaints Though time to sleepe:
I, hearing these complaints, though time to sleep,
I hearing these complaints, though time to sleep,
Satt Sadly Down and with her gan to weepe.
Sat sadly down, and with her ’gan to weep.
Sat sadly down, and with her ’gan to weep.
